name: Wallich's Pheasant
description: Both male and female are brown with a dark pattern, denser in females. The male has a crest on the crown, a prominent red facial wattle, and sharp spurs on its legs.
spread_note: Southern slopes of the western Himalayas
proportions: Body length – females 61–67 cm, males 90–112 cm; tail length – females 32–47 cm, males 45–58 cm; weight – females 900–1,360 g, males 1,250–1,800 g
reproduction: Females lay 10–11 eggs and incubate them for 26 days.
attractions: A sociable species, it forms groups of up to 15 individuals outside the breeding season. The nest is a shallow pit, placed on steep slopes under rock overhangs and well-hidden in vegetation. During incubation, the male stays near the nest and later assists the female in caring for the chicks.
projects_note: Classified as a vulnerable species. The main threats are egg collection and hunting for meat, though it is also endangered by increasing grazing pressure and habitat destruction.
breeding: We have kept Wallich's pheasants since 2011.
